column4: ClassCastException in WPAlertDialogFragment
column5: ClassCastException in WPAlertDialogFragment

column4: 352 reports of this in Google Play dev console. Problem is caused [here](https://github.com/wordpress-mobile/WordPress-Android/blob/develop/src/org/wordpress/android/util/WPAlertDialogFragment.java#L99) by the positive button's onClick() handler assuming the host activity implements OnDialogConfirmListener.
column5: Problem is caused [here](https://github.com/wordpress-mobile/WordPress-Android/blob/develop/src/org/wordpress/android/util/WPAlertDialogFragment.java#L99) by the positive button's onClick() handler assuming the host activity implements OnDialogConfirmListener.

column4: PostUploadService resizes images by first [loading them into memory](https://github.com/wordpress-mobile/WordPress-Android/blob/develop/src/org/wordpress/android/util/PostUploadService.java#L650), which is inefficient and possibly error-prone on "lesser" devices. This needs to be rewritten.

column4: Chart changes width when switching between different data sets
column5: Chart changes width when switching between different data sets

column4:
Chart changes width when switching between different data sets, presumably because its width is dependent on the width of the y-axis label elements ... these should probably be unrelated. 
Maybe better to allow for up to 1M on the y-axis as a max, always, and then let y-axis labels overflow into the chart itself?
column5: Chart changes width when switching between different data sets, presumably because its width is dependent on the width of the y-axis label elements ... these should probably be unrelated.

column4: Do away with "local changes" limitation in the post list refresh
column5: Do away with "local changes" limitation in the post list refresh

column4: Right now the post list silently skips the automatic refresh if local changes exist, since those local changes would be overwritten during the refresh. This means that new posts will never appear during an automatic refresh if there are local changes.
column5: Right now the post list silently skips the automatic refresh if local changes exist, since those local changes would be overwritten during the refresh.

column4: Right now the post list silently skips the automatic refresh if local changes exist, since those local changes would be overwritten during the refresh. This means that new posts will never appear during an automatic refresh if there are local changes.
column5: This means that new posts will never appear during an automatic refresh if there are local changes.

column4: If the refresh was due to the user initiating a pull-to-refresh, the user is presented with this unfriendly dialog:
column5: If the refresh was due to the user initiating a pull-to-refresh, the user is presented with this unfriendly dialog:

column4: Assuming the user understands this dialog, it means we're asking them to choose between seeing new posts and overwriting ones with changes that haven't been uploaded.
column5: Assuming the user understands this dialog, it means we're asking them to choose between seeing new posts and overwriting ones with changes that haven't been uploaded.

column4: The post list should be smart enough to preserve local changes after a refresh, doing away with the need for this dialog and the need to skip automatic refresh if there are local changes.
column5: The post list should be smart enough to preserve local changes after a refresh, doing away with the need for this dialog and the need to skip automatic refresh if there are local changes.

column4: Currently the reader uses `read/sites/{siteId}/posts/{postId}` to request a single post, which is done when entering the detail view to ensure the most recent copy of the post is reflected.
column5: Currently the reader uses `read/sites/{siteId}/posts/{postId}` to request a single post, which is done when entering the detail view to ensure the most recent copy of the post is reflected.

column4: That endpoint is missing the newer feedbag additions, such as `word-count`, which are used by the Calypso reader. To correct this, we should switch to the new v1.2 `/read/feed/:feed/posts/:item` endpoint in both [requestPost()](https://github.com/wordpress-mobile/WordPress-Android/blob/develop/WordPress/src/main/java/org/wordpress/android/ui/reader/actions/ReaderPostActions.java#L216) and [updatePost()](https://github.com/wordpress-mobile/WordPress-Android/blob/develop/WordPress/src/main/java/org/wordpress/android/ui/reader/actions/ReaderPostActions.java#L103).
column5: That endpoint is missing the newer feedbag additions, such as `word-count`, which are used by the Calypso reader.

column4: With high-traffic tags, or with users who don't sync very often, gaps may exist between the most recent existing post and the ones just retrieved from the server. These gaps mean the user is missing posts.
column5: These gaps mean the user is missing posts.

column4: Detect when these gaps occur and provide a way for the user to load the missing posts, similar to how Twitter handles this situation.
column5: Detect when these gaps occur and provide a way for the user to load the missing posts, similar to how Twitter handles this situation.

column4: WordPress 4.4 post date is incorrect
column5: WordPress 4.4 post date is incorrect

column4: There is a bug in WordPress 4.4 that changed the `post_date` from local time to gmt time. https://core.trac.wordpress.org/ticket/35053
column5: There is a bug in WordPress 4.4 that changed the `post_date` from local time to gmt time.

column4: This results in the post not posting at the correct time. The fix will be in 4.4.1, but 4.4 will always have this issue. We'll need a special case for self-hosted sites on 4.4
column5: This results in the post not posting at the correct time.

1. Open the app while logged out
2. Select "Add self-hosted site"
3. Optional: begin to enter your account information
4. Tap on the Help icon (?) in the top right, or exit the app on your device
5. Go back to the login screen
Result: You see the WordPress.com login screen instead of the self-hosted login screen you were just on

column4: Can't schedule a saved draft
column5: Can't schedule a saved draft

column4: Originally reported in https://github.com/wordpress-mobile/WordPress-Editor-Android/issues/269: It isn't possible to schedule a saved draft. Changing the date does not schedule the post, and changing the date and status publishes the post immediately.
column5: It isn't possible to schedule a saved draft.

column4: Originally reported in https://github.com/wordpress-mobile/WordPress-Editor-Android/issues/269: It isn't possible to schedule a saved draft. Changing the date does not schedule the post, and changing the date and status publishes the post immediately.
column5: Changing the date does not schedule the post, and changing the date and status publishes the post immediately.

column4:
### Expected behavior
It should be possible to open a saved draft in the editor and schedule it to be published at a future date.

### Expected behavior
It should be possible to open a saved draft in the editor and schedule it to be published at a future date.
column5: It should be possible to open a saved draft in the editor and schedule it to be published at a future date.

column4:
### Actual behavior
When you try to schedule a saved draft, it is published immediately instead of being scheduled for the future date you select.

### Actual behavior
When you try to schedule a saved draft, it is published immediately instead of being scheduled for the future date you select.
column5: When you try to schedule a saved draft, it is published immediately instead of being scheduled for the future date you select.

column4:
### Steps to reproduce the behavior

1. Create a new post in the app
2. Open the post settings, change the status to Draft, and tap Save
3. Wait for the post to upload and confirm it is saved as a draft
4. Open the draft in the editor
5. Open the post settings, change the publish date to a future date/time, and tap Update
Result: Draft is still saved with current date/time. It isn't scheduled and the future publish date/time is not saved.
6. Open the draft in the editor
7. Open the post settings, change the status to Publish and change the publish date to a future date/time, and tap Schedule

6. Open the draft in the editor
7. Open the post settings, change the status to Publish and change the publish date to a future date/time, and tap Schedule

column4: My Sites: Visit Site view does not display Like button or Likes
column5: My Sites: Visit Site view does not display Like button or Likes

column4:
### Expected behavior

In the `View Site` view from the `My Sites`, the `Like` button and the list of Likes should show up at the bottom of the posts, next to the Follow button. I confirmed that this functions properly on iOS:

### Expected behavior

In the `View Site` view from the `My Sites`, the `Like` button and the list of Likes should show up at the bottom of the posts, next to the Follow button. I confirmed that this functions properly on iOS:
column5: In the `View Site` view from the `My Sites`, the `Like` button and the list of Likes should show up at the bottom of the posts, next to the Follow button.

column4:
### Actual behavior

On Android, this part seems to get stuck with the `Loading ...` message and never populates button or list of Likes:

### Actual behavior

On Android, this part seems to get stuck with the `Loading ...` message and never populates button or list of Likes:
column5: On Android, this part seems to get stuck with the `Loading ...` message and never populates button or list of Likes:

column4:
### Steps to reproduce the behavior

From the `My Sites` screen (the WordPress icon in the top nav bar), select a site (if you are already placed in the site details view, go back one view via `<- SWITCH SITE`). From there, select `View Site`. From here, when you scroll through the post listing on this front-end view of the site, you will notice that the `Like` buttons and list of Likes are not getting rendered but, instead, stuck at `Loading...`. This seems like a pretty minor bug but I thought it was worth reporting anyway, especially since it works on iOS.

### Steps to reproduce the behavior

From the `My Sites` screen (the WordPress icon in the top nav bar), select a site (if you are already placed in the site details view, go back one view via `<- SWITCH SITE`). From there, select `View Site`. From here, when you scroll through the post listing on this front-end view of the site, you will notice that the `Like` buttons and list of Likes are not getting rendered but, instead, stuck at `Loading...`. This seems like a pretty minor bug but I thought it was worth reporting anyway, especially since it works on iOS.
column5: From here, when you scroll through the post listing on this front-end view of the site, you will notice that the `Like` buttons and list of Likes are not getting rendered but, instead, stuck at `Loading...`.

column4: Media: Unable to use photos from library when camera permission has been denied.

column4:
To reproduce:

- From a fresh install open the editor and tap to add media to a post. 
- When prompted to allow access to the camera, tap deny. 
- When prmopted to allow access to the library, allow.

My expectation is WordPress won't have access to my camera but will still be able to pull media from the phone's gallery, or the blog's media library. Instead I see an error message saying that permission is needed.
column5: My expectation is WordPress won't have access to my camera but will still be able to pull media from the phone's gallery, or the blog's media library.

column4: Use a `sortOrder` attribute in ReaderPost model instead of overriding the timestamp
column5: Use a `sortOrder` attribute in ReaderPost model instead of overriding the timestamp

column4:
### Expected behavior
ReaderPost model should have a new attribute that represents the sort order weight for a ReaderPost instance, and all other classes using it should reflect this accordingly
column5:
### Expected behavior
ReaderPost model should have a new attribute that represents the sort order weight for a ReaderPost instance, and all other classes using it should reflect this accordingly

column4:
### Actual behavior
Right now `timestamp`, being used as a sorting criteria, even when sometimes a value other than an actual timestamp is assigned to such `timestamp` attribute, which is misleading.
column5:

column5: Upload and link to full image setting toggle not working

column4: Under a sites settings (My Sites > Choose Site > Settings) there is a toggle to Upload and link to full image. The wording of this is a bit confusing and I'm not entirely sure what it is meant to do.
column5: Under a sites settings (My Sites > Choose Site > Settings) there is a toggle to Upload and link to full image.

column4: Under a sites settings (My Sites > Choose Site > Settings) there is a toggle to Upload and link to full image. The wording of this is a bit confusing and I'm not entirely sure what it is meant to do.
column5: The wording of this is a bit confusing and I'm not entirely sure what it is meant to do.

column4:
### Expected behavior
My expected behavior is if the toggle is turned off when I upload an image to a blog post it would not link the image to the full image.
column5:
### Expected behavior
My expected behavior is if the toggle is turned off when I upload an image to a blog post it would not link the image to the full image.

column4:
### Actual behavior
Whether this is turned on or off (in the legacy editor or the visual editor) when I upload an image to a post it includes a link to the full image.
column5:
### Actual behavior
Whether this is turned on or off (in the legacy editor or the visual editor) when I upload an image to a post it includes a link to the full image.

column4:
### Steps to reproduce the behavior
- Visit My Sites and choose a site
- Click Settings
- Turn off Upload and link to full image
- Start a blog post and add an image
- In visual editor click image and choose to edit, it will include a link to the full image
- In legacy editor publish the post then come back to edit
- Shows code linking to the full image

- Start a blog post and add an image

column4:
### Actual behavior
The message doesn't render the apostrophe correctly, and actually reads as "_Duplicate comment detected; It looks as through you#8217;ve already said that!_
column5:
### Actual behavior
The message doesn't render the apostrophe correctly, and actually reads as "_Duplicate comment detected; It looks as through you#8217;ve already said that!

column4:
### Steps to reproduce the behavior
1. Open the app and tap the notifications icon
2. Scroll down to a comment notification, and open it
3. Use the 'Reply to [Commenter Name] field to submit a comment
4. Once the comment is submitted, try saying the same thing again to trigger the popup
